description: On 16 March, the European Commission announced external border restrictions, meaning that the EU will close its external borders for 30 days, with exemptions for EU citizens coming back home, for healthcare workers, like doctors and nurses, also scientists working on the solution of this health crisis we do see, and for people commuting on borders, who are working on both sides of the border.
target_geog_level: All countries
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description:
On 16 March 2020, the Commission adopted a Communication1
recommending a temporary
restriction of non-essential travel from third countries into the EU+ area2
for one month. On
17 March 2020, the Heads of State or Government of the EU agreed to implement the
temporary restriction of non-essential travel. The four Schengen Associated States also
implemented it.
target_geog_level: An international organization (e.g. World Health Organization)

description: As of March 17, the European Union is introducing a 30-day ban on incoming travel for foreigners to the territory of the Member States in an attempt to limit the spread of the corona-virus pandemic.

description: On 8 April, the Commission invited Schengen Member States and Schengen Associated States to prolong the temporary restriction on non-essential travel to the EU until 15 May. UPDATE: The original restriction of travel has been extended to last to 15 May (instead of only 16 April).
target_geog_level: All countries
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: Starting from 1 July 2020, member states should start lifting the travel restrictions at the external borders for residents of the following third countries: Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and China, the latter subject to confirmation of reciprocity.

description: As an immediate first response, the EU's Emergency Response Coordination Centre coordinated for EU Member States to mobilize and deliver a total of 12 tons of protective equipment to China.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 23 February, the Commission co-financed the delivery of more than 25 tonnes of personal protective equipment to China after the EU Civil Protection Mechanism was activated. UPDATE: In addition to the 12 tonnes of personal protection equipment delivered to China on 1 February, the Commission is co-financing the delivery of more than 25 tonnes of personal protective equipment to China after the EU Civil Protection Mechanism was activated.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 24 February, the European Commission announced that a new aid package worth EUR 232 million to boost global preparedness, prevention and containment of the virus:
- €114 million will support the World Health Organization (WHO), in particular the global preparedness and response global plan. This intends to boost public health emergency preparedness and response work in countries with weak health systems and limited resilience. Part of this funding is subject to the agreement of the EU budgetary authorities.
- €15 million are planned to be allocated in Africa, including to the Institute Pasteur Dakar, Senegal to support measures such as rapid diagnosis and epidemiological surveillance.
- €100 million will go to urgently needed research related to diagnostics, therapeutics and prevention, including €90 million through the Innovative Medicines Initiative, a partnership between the EU and the pharmaceutical industry. *
- €3 million allocated to the EU Civil Protection Mechanism for repatriation flights of EU citizens from Wuhan, China.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Africa,Other Regions (please specify below)

description:
Belgium, 27 February: Our country has placed an important order of protective equipment and masks intended for healthcare professionals. We have also ordered a large supply of masks for patients with a viral infection to protect the people living with them.

The order is part of a ‘joint procurement’ organised by the European Union for its member States. It makes them gain time by avoiding them to carry on separate negotiations with producers and suppliers.

The Belgian government will use this equipment to support general practitioners and hospitals in case of a shortage.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 28 February, the first out of four joint procurements of personal protective equipment, was launched together with Member States. This turns the EU into one big buyer, encouraging suppliers to move quickly at scale and provide the maximum equipment possible at the best price.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: The Commission scaled up the emergency call launched in January to fight the COVID-19 outbreak. The Commission has secured an additional €37.5 million for urgently needed research on COVID-19 vaccine development, treatment and diagnostics, bringing the total funding up to €47.5 million UPDATE: Following the publication of a €10 million call in January, the Commission has secured an additional €37.5 million for urgently needed research on COVID-19 vaccine development, treatment and diagnostics.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: On 15 March, the Commission has taken immediate steps to protect the availability of supplies of personal protective equipment (PPE), by requiring that exports of such equipment outside of the European Union are subject to an export authorisation by Member States.

description: On 16 March, the Commission offered up to EUR 80 million of financial support to CureVac, a highly innovative vaccine developer from Tübingen, Germany, to scale up development and production of a vaccine against the coronavirus in Europe. UPDATE: On 31 January the European Commission announced EUR 10 million are granted from the EU’s research and innovation programme, Horizon 2020, to support research into the new coronavirus disease, and now the Commission is additionally providing EUR 80 million to the company CurVac to scale up development and production of a vaccine against the coronavirus in Europe.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: On 24 March, the European Commission adopted decisions on harmonised standards which will allow manufacturers to place on the market high performing devices to protect patients, health care professionals and citizens in general. The standards will facilitate a faster and less expensive conformity assessment procedure. The revised harmonised standards play a pivotal role in the current coronavirus pandemic because they relate to critical devices.

description:

respirators: speeding up procedures concerning joint procurement
initiatives for personal protective equipment, ventilators and testing
supplies.

description: In a summit meeting on 26 March, the European Council announced that it will promote more corona-related research, including research into a vaccine: 140 million euros have been mobilised for 17 projects, including on vaccines.

description: Finland joins the EU Joint Procurement Agreement to procure medical countermeasures (JPA) on 27 March, to improve the supply of medication and protective personnel equipment in Finland. The purpose of the JPA is to 'strengthen the purchasing power of the Parties and to ensure equal availability, operational security and price balance of medical countermeasures for serious cross-border health threats, such as supplies, equipment and medicines. The Agreement has been signed by 26 EU member states as well as the UK and Norway.

description: On 13 May, Finland receives 10,000 surgical masks purchased by the European Commission. The masks will be delivered to the Logistics Centre of the hospital districts of Helsinki and Uusimaa.

description:
The Commission has mobilised another €122 million from its research and innovation programme,
Horizon 2020, for urgently needed research into the coronavirus. The new call for expressions of
interest contributes to the Commission's €1.4 billion pledge to the Coronavirus Global Response
initiative, launched by President Ursula von der Leyen on 4 May 2020.
The new call is the latest addition to a range of EU-funded research and innovation actions to fight the
coronavirus. It complements earlier actions to develop diagnostics, treatments and vaccines by
strengthening capacity to manufacture and deploying readily available solutions in order to rapidly
address the pressing needs. It will also improve understanding of the behavioural and socio-economic
impacts of the epidemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 23 April, the Europen Parliament and European Council approved the European Commission's proposal to postpone by one year the date of application of the Medical Devices Regulation. The adopted amendment takes into consideration the need for an increased availability of vitally important medical devices across the EU, and at the same time continues to guarantee patient health and safety until the new legislation becomes applicable.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 16 March, the European Commission issued guidelines which aim to harmonize and assist Member States' response to the pandemic, specifically on the topic of borders (inside the EU) between Member States. Guidelines include information on public health and assurance of continuous transport of goods and services.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK)

description:
On 30 March, the European Commission issued guidelines allowing workers with “critical occupations” to cross EU internal borders amid the coronavirus crisis. Such occupations include health professionals, care workers, scientists, medical device
technicians, and others.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: On 2 March, European Commission President von der Leyen established a coronavirus response team at political level to coordinate our response to the pandemic, bringing together all strands of action – from medical, to economic, to mobility and transport.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: As of 10 March, the Commission announced via mandate that it will assemble a team of epidemiologists and virologists from different Member States to give us guidelines on the European level.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: In March, the European Council tasked the High Representative/Vice-President Josep Borrell to coordinate the repatriation operations of the EU citizens and a dedicated Consular Task Force was set up by the European External Action Service. This Task Force works in close cooperation with the Member States and the European Commission. In April it was announced that the coordinated effort managed to bring home more than 500,000 EU citizens who were stranded abroad.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On 10 March, European Commission President von der Leyen announced a “Corona Response Investment Initiative” that should enable around EUR 60 billion of unused cohesion policy funds to be redirected to the fight against the coronavirus.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
On 13 March, the European Parliament issued a (proposed) amendment to a regulation which effectively suspends the "use it or lose it" rule, meaning that airlines are not obliged to use their planned take-off
and landing slots to keep them in the next corresponding season. This prevents airlines from feeling forced to fly empty plans.
type_text: The policy is in the category of travel, as it concerns airline/airport policies

description: On 30 March, the Commission has reallocated EUR 140 million for the most immediate needs in the Eastern Neighbourhood countries, and will redirect the use of existing instruments worth up to EUR 700 million to help mitigate the socio-economic impact of the coronavirus crisis. Similarly, it announced up to EUR 38 million in immediate support for the Western Balkans to tackle the health emergency, and reallocation of EUR 374 million to help the socio-economic recovery.
type_text: This policy provides EU funds aimed at economic and social support of eastern Member States
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 31 March, in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, the EU strengthened its support for refugees from Syria and vulnerable persons in Iraq, Jordan, and Lebanon through a new package of almost EUR 240 million, raising the total assistance via the EU Regional Trust Fund in Response to the Syrian Crisis to more than EUR 2 billion.
type_text: The EU provided a new (economic) package of funds to countries in its Eastern Neighbourhood which are hosting Syrian refugees
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Commission presented an immediate response to mitigate the socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak, centred on a European coordinated response, and via a range of tools, e.g. State aid, flexibility of the European fiscal framework, liquidity to the banking sector, EU budget, and more.
type_text: The European Commission responds to the socio-economic crisis with the following instruments: State aid Framework Flexibility, European Fiscal Framework Flexibility, Ensuring solidarity in the Single Market, Mobilising the EU budget, Alleviating the impact on employment, Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: As of 2 April, the Commission is further increasing its response by proposing to set up a EUR 100 billion solidarity instrument, called SURE, to help workers keep their incomes and help businesses stay afloat. The new instrument that will provide up to €100 billion in loans to countries that need it to ensure that workers receive an income and businesses keep their staff. This allows people to continue to pay their rent, bills and food shopping and helps provide much needed stability to the economy.
type_text: Economic policy aiming to stabilize EU economy
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: On July 1, Vatican City was included in a travel ban restricting entry to Europe from foreign countries.
type_text: Vatican City, not a member of the EU, is going to be considered a part of the bloc for the purposes of a travel regulation restricting entry to the continent.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
